ES - 1.0 | FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Butte County Rice Growers Association (BUCRA) Supply Division, (herein referred to as the Supply Division or Facility) at 1121 Richvale Highway, Richvale, California 95974 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response Plan (ERP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.





ES - 2.0 | FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. The applicable North America Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers). The Supply Division carries the US EPA Facility Identifier number 100-000-160871.



 - Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a liquefied, compressed gas. 

 - Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck (and intermittently, by railcar) and stored in four storage tanks (bullets).

 - The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume.

 - Anhydrous ammonia is converted to aqua ammonia (NH4OH). 

 - Aqua ammonia (NH4OH) is prepared, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.

 - Aqua ammonia (24.3%)  is produced on-site in the facility's converter. 

 - The aqua ammonia is stored in steel tanks at the site. The storage tanks are connected using a piping manifold. The tank valves are kept closed unless actively being filled or drained.

ES - 3.0 | ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



SAFETY INFORMATION:  The Supply Division ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The Supply Division reviews safety information during annual system operator tra

ining. 



HAZARD REVIEW:  The Supply Division conducts a hazard review of the ammonia and aqua ammonia processes every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The Supply Division uses the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Hazard and Operability Study (HazOps) methodology for the review of the regulated substances and processes. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.



OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Written operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures are reviewed on an annual basis and re-certified upon review and/or modification. 



TRAINING:  Supply Division staff, as well as BUCRA corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program is reviewed annual prior to the annual refresher training. The current training program is comprised of the following:

 1. Initial employee training.

 2. Periodic refresher training.

 3. Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.

 4. Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training.

 5. Training records for each employee.



MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training.



RMP MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety

and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures. 



PRE START-UP SAFETY REVIEW:  The pre start-up safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre start-up safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a pre start-up safety review is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. 



COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Supply Division has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.



HOT WORK PERMIT:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, the Supply Division has developed a writ

ten Hot Work Permit program and procedure to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. 



CONTRACTOR SAFETY:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. The Facility also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely.



OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):



Regulated Substances

 - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans

 - United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency Response



Anhydrous Ammonia 

 - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia

 - California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders 

 - Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]



Aqua Ammonia

 - American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping

 - California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials





ES - 4.0 | FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuati

on(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.





ES - 5.0 | THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The facility also developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations ?2745.8. The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) was most recently updated in Calendar Year 2020, reviewed with operations staff on an annual basis, and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.



ES - 6.0 | PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.



ES - 7.0 | THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 78,642 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter hose (or pipe) with an increased wind speed and Pasquill Class "D" stability modeling parameters.



AQUA AMMONIA Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 419,900 pounds of aqua ammonia (equivalent to 102,212.5 lbs of NH3). The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2

-inch diameter hose (or pipe) with an increased wind speed and Pasquill Class "D" stability modeling parameters.
